properties.media:imagetext:
#4
Section 2
Wednesday PM, October 27,1937.
Dear Family:
It's 9 PM.
Mr. Bond and I have just boarded the
good ship
Kung Wo at Hankow.
We
each have a large spacious cabin
and we
are
both turning in before the ship sails.
We have had another busy day
trying all day
to
make our Chinese associates understand a business
proposal
which
would be quite easy for a twelve year old
child to
mater in half an hour?
Such work is what irks one in China.
The men
to
whom
we
wore talking represent the type with whom we must
do business.
It would try
the patience of Job.
After a day of
such negotiations you
are completely worn out.
Thursday, October
Have just been ashore at KinKlang to look see
China shops.
two small porcelain pictures just to have
where the best modern porcelain is made.
All day we have
along the broad Yangtze,
stopping only at Anking about six
o'clock PM.
sampan,
alive with Chinese,
came alongside,
tied up to our boat
while amidst
a scene of utmost chaos
practically
worthless cargo came
coolies.
approximately
similar number got off
with an
walla and confusion of
small baskets,
bundles and boxes.
wounded
soldiers were interesting.
were Nanking boys
wounded in the
fighting
in the north
and were being sent back to their
families in Nankingâ€¢
None of them looked to be over sixteen years old.
are only
four first class
passengers on this large river boat -
are Chinese, one bound for Wuhu where we land
early tomorrow
and the other for Chinklang, a town just upstream from the boom
which the Chinese have stretched
the Yangtsze
the Jap fleet
out of the river.
Oyr Captain and his first mate - both Britishers -
say the boom is
an effective bar to navigation.
It is composed of old
hulks filled with stones and sunk side by side
clear across
the river.
Below the boom an extensive system of mines makes
it dangerous to
approach the boom.
The small
Chinese boats
get around the boom
through a series of canals and are busy
Shanghai cargo around
the boom,
cargo is delivered then
English boats which carry it
in either direction to or away from Shanghal.
Friday, October 29th.
Went to bed at 9 PM and didn't wake up until 8 AM
I'm not
suffering from insomnia.
This morning there is a cold
wind blowing
from the north.
We have
left Wuhu and are due at
Nanking
about noon.
weather is bad
- which is good - because the
Japs can't bomb
with a low ceiling.
If they fly low the anti-aircraft
guns shoot
them down and if they fly high they can't see Nanking because
there is a solid overcoat at about 3000 feet.
Also since International
pressure has been exerted against indiscriminate bombing,
that type of
attack has been
practiced
only against cities and towns
where there are
no influential foreigners.
